data.title: US state telephone codes
data.meta_description: List of telephone area codes in the USA by state and region
data.text:
Structure of North American telephone numbers

The area code is always followed by 7 additional digits of the actual phone number (with the exception of special phone numbers). The first 3 digits originally belong to the respective telecommunications provider. However, these are not the same throughout the country, but are reassigned within each area code. With the introduction of number portability, i.e., the transfer of an existing phone number to another provider, this assignment has been diluted to a large extent. If you apply for a new phone number, you can usually choose from several of these provider-specific numbers. Only the last 4 digits of the number are actually freely assigned.

Map of US area codes

Allocation of the area codes

An area code does not always have to stand for a single city. It can also apply to a larger area with several cities. Conversely, the New York metropolitan area, for example, is divided into several areas because a particularly large number of people live here. Especially in the rapidly growing metropolitan areas, this is hardly sufficient over time. Thus, one assigns additional area codes to a region bit by bit, but not consecutively. Such an assignment of several codes to the same area is called an "overlay". It began in 1947 with 86 numbers. In the meantime, there are more than 450, of which 357 are in the USA alone. Codes with a 0 or 1 at the beginning do not exist. Also, several combinations are reserved for special numbers.

These area codes are assigned according to the North American numbering plan. There, number assignment is planned years in advance for all of North America, including Canada and many Caribbean and Pacific islands.

Not even a rough geographical classification can be made from the numbers. There is no ascending order from west to east or from north to south. Densely populated California alone has 40 area codes ranging from 209 to 951. The District of Columbia has only two area codes (202 and 771).

Therefore, to identify where a phone number originates, extensive lists are used that are already programmed into most phones. This automatically signals to the called party which region the call is coming from.

Unrecognizable mobile numbers

Unlike in most other countries, no individual number ranges or even area codes are provided specifically for mobile communications in the United States. This means that callers cannot tell whether they are calling a fixed-network line or a cell phone. Of course, connections to a mobile network also cost more in the USA than within the traditional fixed network. The surcharge for the mobile connection is therefore borne by the called party. In the past, this could quickly cost a lot of money. Now, however, all U.S. providers offer flat rates that often cost no more than a few dollars per month. This keeps the costs for incoming calls manageable.
